member.name: M:Resco.UIElements.UIElement.SelectNextControl(Resco.UIElements.UIElement,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Moves the focus to the next (or ).
member.param: The UIElement object representing a child of this UIElement at which to start the search.
true to move to the element with higher tab index; false to move to the element with higher tab index.
true to ignore the controls with the UIElement.IsFocusable property set to false; otherwise, false.
true to include nested (children of child elements) child elements; otherwise, false.
true to continue searching from the first control in the tab order after the last control has been reached; otherwise, false.
true to allow focusing the outside that is a sibling of the control.
member.returns: true if an element (or control) was focused; otherwise, false.
member.remarks: This method is an analogy of the . It should be overriden in case of element containing the subelements supporting the keyboard focus.

member.name: P:Resco.UIElements.UIElement.TabStop
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the user can give the focus to this element using the TAB key.
member.value: true if the user can give the focus to the element using the TAB key; otherwise, false. The default is true.
member.remarks: When the user presses the TAB key, the input focus is set to the next element in the tab order. Elements with the TabStop property value of false are not included in the collection of elements in the tab order. The tab order can be manipulated by setting the element's property value.

member.name: P:Resco.UIElements.UIScrollView.TouchScrollFriction
member.summary: Specifies the physical friction that influences the speed of scrolling.

remarks.para: The value must be positive. It specifies the frame rate for scrolling animation. The default value is 10. This value simulates the smooth surface and it is optimal for a list-view with a longer document.
If the slower scrolling is desired (let's say for smaller documents), set the higher friction that will simulate the rough surface and scrolling the scrolling will stop in shorter time.

The OnSelectionChanged method also allows derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate. This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class.
Notes to Inheritors: When overriding OnSelectionChanged in a derived class, be sure to call the base class's OnSelectionChanged method so that registered delegates receive the event.

member.name: P:Resco.UIElements.UIRollerPanel.TouchScrollFriction
member.summary: Specifies the physical friction that influences the speed of scrolling.

remarks.para: The value must be positive. It specifies the frame rate for scrolling animation. The default value is 10. This value simulates the smooth surface and it is optimal for a list-view with a longer document.
If the slower scrolling is desired (let's say for smaller documents), set the higher friction that will simulate the rough surface and scrolling the scrolling will stop in shorter time.

member.name: P:Resco.UIElements.Controls.UIElementPanelControl.TouchScrollFriction
member.summary: Specifies the physical friction that influences the speed of scrolling.

remarks.para: The value must be positive. It specifies the frame rate for scrolling animation. The default value is 10. This value simulates the smooth surface and it is optimal for a list-view with a longer document.
If the slower scrolling is desired (let's say for smaller documents), set the higher friction that will simulate the rough surface and scrolling the scrolling will stop in shorter time.

member.name: P:Resco.UIElements.UIProgressBar.Step
member.summary: Gets or sets the amount by which a call to the method increases the current position of the progress bar.
member.value: The amount by which to increment the progress bar with each call to the method. The default is 10.

remarks.p: You can use the Step property to specify the amount that each completed task in an operation changes the value of the progress bar.
For marquee styled progress bar, this property specifies the amount the progress bar block moves each time.

member.name: P:Resco.UIElements.UIProgressBar.MarqueeAnimationSpeed
member.summary: Gets or sets the time period, in milliseconds, that it takes the progress block to scroll across the progress bar.
member.value: The time period, in milliseconds, that it takes the progress block to scroll across the progress bar. The default is 100.

remarks.p: A marquee-style progress indicator does not display progress; instead it indicates that an operation is occurring by moving the progress block across the progress bar.
Since the marquee animation speed is a time period, setting the value to a higher number results in a slower speed and a lower number results in a faster speed.
The speed of the marquee animation also depends on property.

member.name: E:Resco.UIElements.UINumericUpDown.ValueChanged
member.summary: Occurs when the property has been changed in some way.
member.remarks: For the ValueChanged event to occur, the property can be changed in code, by clicking the up or down button, or by the user entering a new value that is read by the control. The new value is read when the user hits the ENTER key or navigates away from the control. If the user enters a new value and then clicks the up or down button, the ValueChanged event will occur twice.
